bioghist.p: The Pennsylvania Horticultural Society is Americaâ€™s first horticultural society and was formed in 1827 as a not-for-profit membership organization. The McLean Library, formed shortly after the founding of the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society, currently holds over 15,000 volumes on gardening and plant care, botany, and urban greening. The collection serves the needs of amateur and professional horticulturists, landscape architects, garden historians, and researchers. It is used by the public and by the society's members and volunteers. The collection supports the horticultural and urban greening activities of the staff. The McLean Library's holdings include the Mary Helen Wingate Lloyd Collection, which consists of significant European and American gardening imprints from the 16th-20th centuries, and the Society's archives.

scopecontent.p: These volumes document the holdings and accounts of the Library of the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society. Records include: an accession book, undated, listing title, author, place of publication, date, and size for the first 531 volumes in the library's holdings; a library catalogue in manuscript from 1839, which lists holdings alphabetically and numerically by accession number, and which also contains some circulation records, memoranda of books donated to the library (1829-1841), and minutes of the Council of the Society from 1831 to 1834; a library catalogue in manuscript from 1894, which lists holdings by topic, by author, by title, and by accession number; two librarian's account books (1839-1885 and 1839-1864), which record circulation of holdings among members, income from appropriations from the Society's funds and library fines, expenses (primarily book purchases), and memoranda relating to the establishment of the library copied from the Society's minute books; and an inventory of the Mary Helen Wingate Lloyd collection with bibliographic, provenance, and binding information for each title.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
